I bought Ryse Son Of Rome during a sale for 4.99, I had been following the game since the release of it on the Xbox One back during its launch, and was delighted when I heard it was coming to PC. I am a huge fan of Roman History and had always liked Sword Fighting Games so this was a win win.   Pros:   The Game looks and runs Beautifully, It ran at most of the time 60FPS at 1080P with all settings maxed out on a GTX 980 Ti.  I loved the story, although it is only 8 chapters long, Marius's story is inspirational, and Voice Acting is well done.  Combat is Brutal and fun to watch.  Good Soundtrack.  Formation during missions is awesome and realistic.  Upgrades for more brutal executions.  Focus Mode.   Online COOP.   Cons: The game does suffer from FPS dips, especially in more densely vegetated areas or when surrounded in combat by multiple enemies.   Multiplayer rank 200 is a grind to get to.  Overall I really enjoyed Ryse Son Of Rome and am really happy that I got the chance to play and experience it on the PC.  My Review Score:  9 OUT OF 10, FANTASTIC GAME, DEVELOPERS DESERVE PRAISE FOR THE TIME AND EFFORT PUT IN.

Yeah, I dont really understand why this game was slammed so much. I thought it was really fun as hell. The graphics were really impressive, the story was actually pretty cool and pretty accurate to the timepiece, the characters were believable, the voice acting (and especially the main character) was amazing, the combat was intense. All around good game. In fact, the combat seemed to be the major complaint I read about the game and I really dont see it. the basic parry attack system was simple but effective and those executions....those were flat out awesome and never got old! The actual game length for me was about 8 hours, and I think co-op could easily extend this by at least as much.  I really recommend trying this one out. Despite the negative press upon its Xbone release, I can say for certain that the game is stellar at this point in time and well worth your consideration.   An all around solid 8 out of 10 for me. I would and will play this one again.

A short beautiful and cinematic eye pleaser that fails to deliver in just about every other way.   There's a lot of things I didn't like about this game but when it boils down to it, I enjoyed the presentation enough to overlook it's many pitfalls. This is a mini-series more than it is a game. Every level is a perfectly constructed stage. Every piece of action and each event is designed to keep pushing you forward at great pace. Every time the camera is out of your control whether in game or in cutscenes the directing and cinematography is perfectly framed. The actors, both digital and vocal, are amazing. The audio aspects are top notch. All of this keeps you engaged to the end. But you're stuck playing entirely on someone else's terms. You're merely a pawn of the video games Gods in this one.   The pace of the game was superb. Beyond the atrociously bad and repetitive boss fights you never had time to breathe. That only had one drawback because unlike other games in a similar vein you never felt encouraged to just take it all in. The environments and levels are meticulously filled with beauty but save for some very few uninteresting collectibles you have no desire to ever just admire and explore your surroundings. You're splashing headlong down an ever tightening funnel. Which is well and good as the pace builds adrenaline.  Adrenaline that you instantly dump upon getting into a battle. I can't imagine anything but using a controller on this one but combat basically amounts to the dreadful 'timed button mashing'. No combos, no skill required, no nuance. Just timing and patience. Dull dull patience. The only glimpses of satisfaction are quick-time event finishers... That get old fast. But those finishers are used to replenish health, or earn extra focus/damage/XP. So you have to do them like the pawn you are. Endlessly. I'd say I spent, conservatively guesstimating, at least thirty minutes of my five hours thirty minutes of playtime watching finishers. Gruesome and awesome finishers admittedly, but again, they got old. You can count the ultra-basic standard enemy types on one hand. And that same count is the amount of models you're presented with. No gear or clothes change ups, just endless barbarian clones for slaughter. The fat ones all have shields, the tall ones all have the same fur cloak, etc. Then the bosses... Oh the bosses. They're just drawn out versions of the standard hordes. But you can't be offensive. You just have to wait your turn to strike. Repeat with a block or dodge until your number is called, then strike. Only on their terms. Circle around and hit em from behind? Nope, they will have none of that! Afterall, you are but a pawn.   The story itself is average but engaging. With how much you have to turn your brain off for the combat anything more from the story would of made this more of a heartbreaking missed opportunity. So I was satisfied with the story. Especially with the very fitting ending. It was beyond appropriate for this game experience. But while the story serves as the force that keeps pushing the pace, its the visual experience that is all that you're after here. With any other aspect you have to keep your expectations reeled in quite tight. I enjoyed the parts where I was along for the ride, and trudged through the bad gameplay to get to the next part of the ride. Of course opportunities were missed and I definitely do wish the gameplay was more than it was.   I didn't like the menus, there's a technical complaint or two with how it ran on my toaster, I didn't even try keyboard and mouse, nor did I try multiplayer, and I'm sure something else is escaping me as well. And my recommendation is only if it is on sale for < $4.99USD or bundled. But. I do recommend it simply for the direction or cinematography or whatever you want to call it.

If you're a history buff in love with the period of Roman Empire, this game might be a bitter piece of entertainment for you. Even more than the 'Gladiator'. You can't pinpoint any dates in the game. All we know, is that the action takes place between AD 60 (when the Iceni rebellion took place) and AD 90s ( Nero, who looks in this game as an old man in his sixties, in fact died in 68 at the age of thirty).  But this is just the tip of the iceberg. Nothing in this game makes any bloody sense. Eboracum is called York, despite the modern name wasn't in use until well into Norman Period.. but that's fine, because the fortifications of York look very medieval - but don't worry, barbarians are fully equipped with advanced siege engines - so the odds are even!  I could go on with countless examples of historical faux pas, but let me just say one thing: When you see Boudica riding a war elephant.. you know you reached the bottom of fanficition bucket and below there are only My Little Pony ships and HBO's Game of Thrones.  Now, that said - the game is fun for what it is. It's a simplistic button-masher with QTEs (I normally don't like them, but in this game, they work fine). Combat is simple, but performing executions is very satisfying - especially if you do your QTEs right. If you won't - that's fine too, but you'll get lower bonus. There are only few, if any, moments in the game when failing a single QTEs will kill you. Fighting system lacks depth and even ability to level up your skills doesn't improve that.  You can master the combat system within one afternoon... and that is pretty much how much it will take you to finish the game, sadly.  That is a big, massive let down. The game is surprinsgly short. Chance to build up the character relations and thicken the plot is squished within experience lasting but few hours. You get bare-bones of what seems to be an interesting story arc of gods playing their games using mortals as pawns. That's pretty much the only interesting thing in this whole storyline, everything else seems to be glued together by someone who had barely any clue about writing scripts.  While the game follows, to the letter, the Three Act Structure, it falls short on each of them - exposition leaves you clueless about what is really going on, second act fails at creating compelling character development and the climax feels artificial because you have barely any emotions towards main antagonist... whoever he might be (I'm still not sure...).     At the beginning Marius sees the Barbrians as the threat, towards mid-game you're introduced to Boudica and Oswald (... seriously? Saxon names in 1st century AD. How about Caratacus? Yeah, he wasn't Boudica's father, but we already established nobody cares about historical facts here...). And then the perspective changes - Roman leaders, sons of Nero, turn out to be half-crazy butchers and Britons start to look like people who just defend themselves from injustice. Marius goes on a rampage killing both sons of Nero and eventually goes after Nero himself.. (but not before killing Boudica leading attack on Rome) just to be introduced in the last scene to the true villain who was behind all the events from the very start - Aquilon, god of north wind who wants to destroy 'civilization' (WHAAAT?). You can see why building up emotions towards antagonists is so difficult - there are too many of them and they have too little screen time.     I blame mostly the lenght of the game for all of this - given more time for Acts I and II you could have much more compelling build up to the climax - which actually feels like the most expanded part of the game, as you deal one by one with all antagonists you barely care about.  Ryse shines however, when it comes to voice acting - which somewhat midigates medicore (at best) plot. Game has very distinct, pleasant artstyle and atmosphere - something between Lord of the Rings and 300. Put together with great care for details, the game can make you stop and look at the world around. Graphics are very good, with superb motion capture. End result is more than just sum of it's parts - as you get extremely well executed scenes where every detail is taken care of. You can watch cut-scenes with finger over F12, making screenshots of some of the most outstanding scenes and locations. It can almost make you forget the story is laughable... almost.  All in all, Ryse is a title that you should approach with low expectations towards historical fidelity and depth. It's good piece of mindless enterteiment for few hours. And that's all it really is.  You can get few more extra hours out of the game with the multiplayer and skirmishes, but all in all, the game doesn't change much - you just fight same enemies in different places with arena mechanics.   I give the game cautious recommendation - but buy it only if it's on sale. Don't pay more than 10 dollars/euro - the game isn't worth more. I don't recommend it to people who are historical puritans, who loves realism and/or deep combat.

Ryse: Son of Rome is one of those games that looks amazing and great at first sight, but after a few hours of playing it becomes repetive and boring. While this sounds really negative and might convince you not to buy this game is understandable, but hear me out for a sec.  I definitly don't recommend this game for the full price. Buy it in a sale when it's really cheap, because most people won't make it past 10 hours of playtime (this includes the whole singleplayer storyline).  However for some achievementhunters like myself, the game (and definitly the multiplayer stuff) might stay fun for a longer time. In my opinion the multiplayer arenas were fun for a while, but the challenges stay the same so they can get boring fast. The only part of this game I really enjoyed was the survival co-op gamemode, it's quite challenging and can really test your skill. It's only unfortunate that it's the least popular gamemode or it takes the longest to pair me at least.  The biggest problem with this game however is how it bugs out all the time and it doesn't do what you want or the camera gets stuck in weird angles or the animations take longer than they seem to (but maybe that's some lagg from my computer). And these problems only get worse if you play on legendary mode. Normally you can play the game at an easy pace, but on legendary mode (when you're threatened a lot of the time and your moves are more critical) it bugged me a lot how it seemed the game was screwing me.  So yeah, to end this review I'll say that overal I enjoyed playing this game and will play some more co-op in the future. Most of my problems were with the singleplayer and legendary mode, although the story itself is pretty decent (only really short). Another problem could be that the gameplay is a bit repetitive, but this will depend from person to person. So I DO recommend this game, only not at full price!  Thank you for reading.

I feel as though I am in a film (which is as the developers wanted us to feel) with the story line taking me from one scene to another, totally absorbed in the moment... and that moment always leads to extreme violence and death, and there are many of Rome's enemies to deal with and kill. Yes, on the down side there could be more and varied AI warriors to despatch, many look the same, but the whole feeling of being part of it all as the story unwinds, plus the amazing graphics and detail of the characters and landscapes really shine through. The game is not a history lesson, it is not a study on the Roman Empire. It is simply an outstanding adventure story, set in Roman times, and I'm loving every minute of it!

Overall: An enjoyable romp through some viseral and eyecatching combat, let down by the short and narrow story along with poor boss fights.

The game is good for what it is, but realize what it is: a linear, hack and slash title. It's also not that long, but that's not necessarily a negative, given the nature of the game. My overall rating for the game is 7/10. It was definitely worth the $10 I paid for it, and I think it wouldn't be a terrible buy for even $20, but I wouldn't pay any more than that.  On paper it seems like I'd hate the game since it's a pretty repetitive hack and slasher, but somehow it ends up being more than the sum of its parts. I thought the combat did a good job of capturing the brutal and visceral nature of close combat. It was fun enough to play, even if it was pretty repetitive. The story was also solid, and I think that helped the game a lot. It held your attention and kept you motivated to fight through each part. Had the story been bad, I'm not sure how enjoyable the overall game would have been.   The graphics were also pretty good, and felt like they captured the feeling of ancient Rome, although at some points the architecture was pretty clearly exaggerated compared to reality. The environments are definitely not 100% historically accurate, but I could accept the areas where creative license was taken. The Arena section, in particular, was pretty cool. The levels were all totally linear, but that seemed to work alright for this game.   The upgrade system to me seemed like it served very little purpose. In my opinion, you might as well have automatically leveled up. I bought upgrades throughout the game, and they probably helped, but nothing I purchased had an obvious impact on the game play. I didn't even spend all my exp toward the end of the game, as I simply forgot to do so, and it really didn't seem to make much difference (granted at that point I was already pretty upgraded). It just seemed odd to me that they went to such effort to add an XP system, but then didn't really do much with it.   Lengthwise the game was pretty short. I estimate that it only took me about 6 - 6.5 hours to play through. Steam says 7 hours, but I know there was some AFK time in there. That being said, I think the length was actually a positive, because the game play could not have held my interest for more than another hour or two. If the game was 8 hours instead of 6, I doubt I'd have gone away with such a positive impression.   Overall, my biggest complaint is I feel the game could have been so much more than what it was. I think they had a solid core idea with the combat, and the story/setting, but they should have expanded on it somehow. I'm not sure exactly what direction I think they should have taken things, just that they missed the boat somehow -- the story and setting had a lot more potential than what the game ultimately delivered.

First, get a good computer. Second, adjust the graphical and texture settings for good performance. Third, enjoy the game. P.S Lots of blood, beware.  Good game with lots of depth with simple controls, and good story telling. Although, the skill system is pretty pointless because you get enough points to unlock them all. Would have been better to have a system where you must sacrifice choices.  In terms of gameplay, the game has some performance issues with stuttering in some high graphical areas (this has been experienced with players across all computer spectrums, from low-end to high-end). That can be ignored to some extent, but quite annoying. No fix yet (since 2014).  If you are a collection or achievement type of person, the game has many collectables. It also rewards players for exploration so you will always get something other than fighting around (beware the game is still going to be combat related, treat this like a side dish rather than the big meal).  The combat is simple and elegant, unlike other fighter games where combos require multiple button setups, the game focuses on timing and usage of perks. So anyone can get into the game, learn it quickly, but hard to master.  Multiplayer, does not have many players, so do not expect getting CO-OP matches or what not quickly. But still enjoyable for playing with friends (not so much for single players unless you want to be on the leaderboards).  Music is amazing and probably made the game a lot stronger than it was. Many times the music adds a layer emotion that attaches you to the character or makes connections to yourself. (So play with headphones or a good sound system)  Visuals, I am not much of a visual type of person. But graphical setups and scenes were good and well done. The game brings you through several environments and show off the Crytek Engine like deep green jungles, the english channel, the streets of Rome, and dark dense forests. I really enjoyed the invasion scene with the boats and fighting on the streets of York.   Story, some characters were pointless in the story. The gods are a good example because they did not have any depth other than being plot to forward the story. Most of the antagonists or villains were under developed and just silly with some exceptions in good character design.   For example, Commodus, Nero and Basillius could have been any spoiled rich kid with a superiority complex. Nothing interesting about them.   Characters that were good, Boudica, King Oswald and Vitallion. Their character shines out without plot and the player can make judgements about their lives without the game giving it to you.  (On the fence with the main character, his personality goes all over the place, from loving son to revenge driven solider, to vengeful spirit and to defender of Rome.) There is no core values or spirit in the character, he is pretty empty with goals that drive him. His entire journey to fight was based on revenge from the beginning of the game until the invasion of Rome.   His character really fleshes out during the end of the game where he defends Rome with Vitallion, but other than that, there are many disconnects in his character from the beginning to the end of the game.   In other words, his character goes from a naive revenge driven son to an honourable hero of Rome within one day. That is a pretty big personality change that no real human being truly experiences. Bring it down a notch.   Overall, the game gets a 8/10 on my list.

Really enjoyed this game, It's refreshing to find a game that actually challenges you to make decisions. First, I have to start with the obvious, the visuals. The beginning loads up into a cut scene to begin the story, so I'm sat there watching, drinking my coffee and then realised that I was being slowly hacked to bits by Barbarians, I thought it was still a frickin cutscene! The graphics are absolutely gorgeous, the attention to detail is immense without a single element of lag, fantastic work by the developers. Combat can be slightly frustrating, particularly against some of the later boss characters where you have to combine dodge, with perfect and I mean pin-point precision blocking moves followed up with a quick attack. Initially, the combat is great and the execution moves are a nice touch but just when it starts to get repetitive, the developers throw a few elements into the mix, like the scorpion artillery piece which really is a rapid fire machine gun (not entirely historically accurate) or commanding troops ducking behind shield wall formations at the click of a button whilst being fired on by archers. Their are some features of the game which blatantly copies other games such as focus (Think Max Payne and several other games of note) and some features which are don't really have much of an affect like the ability to build up your damage meter. Character progression is great being able to upgrade your execution moves and so on. My only gribe about this game is replayability, I finished the game in 2 days and now am looking for the next best thing. I have yet to try multi-player and will update this review when I do. Overal though, if you want a decent John Cena turned Roman Soldier meets Gears of War with the ability to chop off a barbarians arm with the swing of a sword, then this is game for you but don't expect to replay the story line because once done, the surprise elements are gone. 8/10

This is Call of Duty: Ancient Warfare -- a backhanded compliment if ever there was one.  Obviously, the emphasis is on melee weaponry, not ranged. Combat is very similar to the Arkham games, both in terms of presentation and mechanics. Attacks are telegraphed with brightly-colored icons above the attacker's heads, and a well-timed shield block will stagger the enemy, allowing for several hits. There are two sword attacks (light & heavy) and one shield-bash attack, which does little damage but causes the enemy to drop his guard. The formula for killing an enemy with no shield is light, light, shield, heavy, shield, repeat if necessary. For an enemy with a shield, open with a shield attack instead, but otherwise, it's the same formula. There's room for adding a little variety just for fun -- I like lowering two enemies to execution level and then taking both out with one execution -- and there's a fun but basically unnecessary bullet-time mechanic called Focus, but it's a little too easy to fall into a wrote routine.  Lowering an enemy's health below a certain threshold makes a skull appear above their heads, indicating that you can press E to execute them. Execution involves -- hold on to something here, people -- quicktime events. But relax. First of all, they're dirt simple; ony two buttons (blue for sword, yellow for shield) are ever called for. You can handle two buttons. And if you can't, guess what? Hitting the wrong button doesn't fail the event, it just awards you a lesser bonus. Any quicktime event you can simply ignore with minimal consequence, won't feel that much like a QTE. Honestly, I hate QTEs, and put off buying this game just because they come up every 30 seconds. Now that I've played it, it's fine. It doesn't detract from my fun at all, and I thought it would make me ragequit. Just FYI.  There's a high cut-scene/gameplay ratio, and they are un-pausable and un-skippable. I usually hate that, too, but it's just so pretty that I loved kicking back and soaking it in. It's really, really beautiful. Your character, Marius (not the historical Gaius Marius, but probably loosely based on him) is extremely well modeled and animated.  It's very short and very linear. I didn't chase achievements, and took about 8 hours to finish the game. That's way too short for a full-price game, but I picked this up on sale for $15, and I think that's a perfectly fair price for 6-8 hours of gory, macho, dude-bro ancient-world magnificence. If you see it for that much or less, pick it up. It's jolly good fun. If it's not on sale, pick up the cheapest Arkham game you don't already own for a very similar experience with way more content, and Batman.  Also, Marius looks kind of like Clive Owen, if he were built like a linebacker, and Clive Owen is cool. So, there's also that.

I heard a lot of bad things about this game and thus I always avoided it. The biggest complaint I heard was that it is reptitive. And I'm here to tell you that...it is. There's a moment where you're storming a beach with flaming arrows raining down from the sky in a cloud that absolutely floored me.  Combat. Yes, it's repetitive, but I, personally, find it fun. You wear your enemies down and then execute them via QTE. There are multiple executions you can unlock and I haven't grown tired of them yet. The damage physics are also cool, cuts appear on their bodies, their noses bust, it really feels like you're doing some damage.  Mission Variety. I haven't beaten the game yet, but so far I've fought on a palace wall, a market, a courtyard, a senate floor, and a rain soaked beach. I'm over an hour in, but I hear it's a 7 hour game.  Voice Acting. This game is extremely well acted, there really haven't been any lines that have rung false. Even the pre-combat speeches are rousing, like the opening to Gladiator via video game.  Cons  Story. It isn't anything special. Usual sword and sandals, 'I will have my vengeance' fare.  Camera. I fought with it a few times, especially when 4 or 5 guys were surrounding me. It has gotten stuck on the architecture and they've gotten a few cheap blows in on me because of it.  In conclusion  So far I'd give it an 8 out of 10. I dont' see that changing. This game is a really polished hack and slash with incredible graphics. It's fun. Something to boot up when you want some mindless fun.   Is it worth 60 dollars? No way. It's definitely worth 20. Just finished the campaign. I have not tried multiplayer but single player experience alone is worth the cost in my opinion.  Pros -Executions (like the slow motion action scenes in God of War). Marius, the protagonist, is magnanimous. He's genuinely a good soldier who just wants to defend Rome and make his father proud. But if you cross him, he will make you suffer. And I love it. I love it even more in slow motion. I love it so much I wish I knew how to better control which executions I use. I think it's based on your position relative to the enemy when you initiate the execution command. -Visuals. The detail is incredible. I love that you have fluid camera rotation out the box. As you do slow motion action scenes, you can usual move the camera around to take in all the surroundings. -Story Length. While the story is short with unsurprising plot twists, it's solid enough. The game is basically replaying the story of Marius becoming a soldier like his father leading up to the point where Marius is alone with the emporer (the game introduction). Most people like in long,complicated plots; but in my opinion they kept the story details brief and kept action as the focus. HUGE PLUS FOR ME. -Responsive controls. There's no lag. In fact, I find the control inputs to be quick and forgiving for an action game. You can put a last second block in when you should have gotten hit. -Multiplayer options. While I haven't played multiplayer, you have options to do several different modes including what looks like a co-op story mode, arena, and survival. I like that they give multiple options here. -Save Points. The game automatically saves. OFTEN. You can't manually save as far as I know but there'd never be a need to. You will always restart at the latest fight. And there is a lot of fighting :) .  Cons -Story length is a pro and a con. While Marius' story is certainly satisfying in the sense of what events take place and how he handles them, some of the supporting characters (namely the two not-so-surprising reveals near the end) did not have enough depth. I believe it's due to the pace of the story. The story could have easily been told in the same amount of time without those two characters included. In fact, I believe the whole story could have been focused on Marius, Vatticus? (the general Marius reported to), the emporers, and the barbians. Even the small details they give the barbarian female could have been left out because most of her dialogue is yelling. It's nothing meaningful. She's just mad and yells. A. LOT. Kudos to whoever voiced her because she at least sounds believable. -Control explanations. The game does introduce most of the controls. However, I do not remember them ever explaining what focus was. Maybe I missed that. Needless to say, you can play the entire campaign without using it. -Picking up projectiles. It is extremely rare that you have to stop and pick anything up. In most cases, it's to get spears. But for whatever reason, the hitbox for picking up spears is so small you often sit there spamming E while Marius does a dagger flip move instead of picking anything up. It's incredibly annoying because it breaks the flow of the otherwise smooth and beautiful game. And because the controls are so responsive, you'll probably dagger flip 3 times before realizing you're not going to pick up anything. -Execution difficulty. It seems like even if you don't input the executions correctly, Marius still wins the brawl. The only punishment I found from messing up execution commands is that I get less points. Seems like it would be more exciting to have the enemy break out of the execution if I mess up too many. But even if you get all the commands wrong, Marius will still kill the enemy.  TLDR: Get this game if you want to use a sword and shield to kill waves of people similar to God-of-War style. Keep in mind the plot is short but sweet. Ryse: Son of Rome is pretty much 60% action game and 40% movie with nearly seemless transitions between two parts.

Ryse: Son of Rome is about going to beautiful places and repeatedly stabbing everyone you meet there.   Ryse’s story is delivered out of chronological order. Rome is crumbling under a barbarian assault, and Marius, a proud and decorated Centurion, is escorting Emperor Nero through his palace. One moment later, Marius is a fresh-faced greenhorn of the Roman army. As I progressed, I enjoyed learning more about how the circumstances became so dire. And despite the abnormal structure, the story was never difficult to follow even when it took a few unanticipated turns.  Ryse’s biggest issue is that not even halfway through its modest six-hour campaign, you’ll have seen and experienced a vast majority of your offensive options. Combat consists of basic hits, bashes, blocks, and heavy attacks.  Enemy variety does a bit of work to liven things up. Some foes are unblockable, some charge you, and some assault you with a flurry of dual-sword attacks. Dealing with them requires you to care about your blocks, attacks, and movements, which is fun until you figure out their repetitive patterns.  With my GeForce 980-equipped PC I played Ryse without a hiccup.

The fighting mechanism I found to be slightly redundant but ultimately satisfying. You can scythe through hordes of the lower level enemy characters until more advanced characters join the fray to keep things interesting. There are several featured showdowns against heavily armored and heavy attacking characters that require finesse and careful timing of parry or deflect keystrokes to defeat. The execution feature adds a welcome element of stragety to the melee combat too. After giving an enemy character enough damage you can execute by following the on-screen cues. The more accurately you match the slash or shield maul attacks in an execution the bigger bonus you get to choose from, either health, focus (for activating a temporary slo-mo butcher fest), damage increase (good for taking out enemies with huge health stats), or experience (I don't use that because you can get XP easily anyway).  There are short portions of the game where you lead your fellow Romans in testuodo formations and javelin hurling. FINALLY I would ***highly recommend*** setting the difficulty to centurion or legendary if you are an experienced hack'n'slash gamer. I with relatively little experience picked up the game on Centurion difficulty.  Final Grade: -Ambience +A -Story A -Gameplay B+  Overall: A

The combat system is also repetitive, as you must perform a Q.T.E. on every enemy when killing them in order to reap the most bonuses. These executions become boring after a while. Overall the combat is really more about getting the Q.T.E.'s correctly timed than actually strategically dodging and hitting, etc.  Therefore, the game will never really live up to the great action RPGs like Dark Souls in terms of depth of combat, it doesn't even come close. You are always forced to use one weapon, one shield, and one type of armor for one speed. The combat is quite shallow and lacks any customization besides upgrading. Its greatest strength lies in the amazing setting and levels, even if I wish there was more time to explore them rather than just run through linear levels beating up bad guys. There was obviously a ton of work put into making the levels look realistic, but a lot of that work will probably go unappreciated due to the speed the game pushes you through the levels.

At full price, it's just not worth it. I also highly suggest a controller to play this game.   Ryse: Son of Rome is an interesting game that takes place in Ancient Rome (duh!). You control Marius, a Roman centurion whose primary motivation is made clear within the first half hour of the game. I was looking forward to playing this game as I typically enjoy third-person combat games and Ancient Rome is a location that not many games have mined for material yet. Obviously, there are some good Rome-based games already in existence, but the cinematic action genre has not been done in this specific time period. I liked this game on some levels, disliked on others, and overall it's the absolute definition of a mixed bag.  Here's some basic stats followed by a tl;dr selection of Pros/Cons.  I have played only the story mode. I played at 'normal' difficulty and I have not touched any mode but the story. Steam has my playtime clocked at 6.3 hours, a very short experience needless to say. I may consider returning to it and playing the 'Legendary' difficulty in the future, but I have no interest in the multiplayer.  Pros + It looks absolutely outstanding.  + Has some of the best facial animations ever. + Voice acting is solid. Supporting characters are memorable due to this. + There are some very cool set pieces/big action sequences that are done really well. + Soundtrack is fitting.   Cons - Extremely short single player game. - Story is predictable, full of cliches, with some very laughable lines.  - Gameplay is very monotonous. - There is an extreme amount of quick-time events (QTE).  - The attempts to vary the gameplay are few and when there are variations, they're done weakly.  - Historical accuracy was not something the developers took seriously.  I really wanted to like this game more than I do sitting here after completing it. Crytek did an absolutely outstanding job in the graphics department. There are variations in setting that help the story plow along and again, look great. That said, I can find fault in just about every single one of my 'Pros' bar the looks department. There are numerous cutscenes and for the most part they look great so I enjoyed them in this respect. I also liked the way the game goes from cutscene to play almost seamlessly in some areas. Facial animations are great both during play and throughout.  Combat is of a very run of the mill design. Heavy attack, quick attack, shield attack, and block. The game is designed for consoles, so playing with a controller is HIGHLY recommended. There is little variation in enemies. At first glance, one of the cooler gameplay elements is in respect to executions. Virtually every enemy you fight (aside from bosses) will allow you at some point in the fight to pull off an execution. This involves the game entering a QTE and then you hit the corresponding button. If you hit the right button, you get more 'Valor' points, which is the in-game currency to upgrade Marius' health, focus, and combat. This mechanic gets extremely old rather quickly. Unfortunately, its wise to enter executions regularly because it allows you to fill up your focus bar to enter what is essentially a powered up mode where you're super powerful and super fast. I also find fault with the executions because there are only so many variations. Early on, you will see them all and then the QTEs start becoming a chore. Another aspect of combat is that actions are signaled to you using color, rather than the typical A, B, X, etc. If you're not using an Xbox branded controller, this may become awkward for you. I do not believe there is a way to change this, but as I have an Xbox controller, I didnt bother to look. I imagine playing with a keyboard and mouse would be very cumbersome. To put it simply, the combat gets boring. Its not like the Arkham games where you're looking for a fight.  There are portions of the gameplay where it is varied, but they are few and not many. There are attempts at a mini-strategy game which eerily reminded me of the portions of Assassins Creed Revelations' tower defense mode. Basically you're made to position certain elements of your army to defend a position. Its not executed very well and one wrong placement could mean your doom. One change in gameplay I did like was when you're in formation marching on an enemy position. It looks cool and gives you the feeling of power. However, the execution of this is one dimensional and also very easy.   The story is not the worst I've ever experienced by any stretch, but it just wasn't that strong or enough to make me want to play again anytime soon. The predictability hurt it a lot, along with some really hokey 'supernatural' elements that are of no help to its quality. Marius is your standard Russell Crowe/Gerard Butler-esque hybrid cliche, but the voice acting is well done in virtually every respect, so it at least goes down smoothly. The score is decent and fitting, but not very memorable. Historical accuracy is not completely non-existant, but there are some aspects that stand out (an auto-loading crossbow that acts as a mounted machine gun weapon) as being stupid and impossible for the time period.  All in all, I really wanted to like this game more. I cannot stress enough how good it looks and I experienced no problems technically whatsoever bar getting stuck in an area once. There are some excellent sequences that are VERY memorable (the Colosseum sequence is AWESOME), but on whole its such a short experience and doesn't do much to seperate itself from the crowded action game pack outside of its fantastic looks. The gameplay itself is a real letdown and gets old quickly.  All of this said, I cannot recommend this game at it's $39.99 price point. At 50% or more off, I think it would be easier to recommend, but save your $40. Ryse can wait.  6/10

It only get's harder with very hard to block enemies and archers, but other than that the same enemies attack in hordes and get slaughtered in the same execution moves over and over. And the execution moves are a joke again, since you can press any buttom (or no button at all) to finish them. Pressing the right one at the right time gains you some bonus and scrolling the mousewheel like crazy gives you some bonus too. But no skill needed for these.  The ranged combat is a mess. Throwing your spears locks to any target it wants, even to targets out of your sight and you see your character throwing at you to some enemy behind you. Also you don't see any spears on your character, as I said, everything looks nice but is very shallow. Using the various mounted ranged weapons, they can feel awesome when the enemy is near and comical when the enmy is far and stands up and ducks like some games on a fair.  The skill tree is a joke. You can just upgrade your overall statistics and get new exection moves, but nothing feels different. There is almost no progress that you can see or feel in any way.  So: if you buy this game for under 5 Euro/$ it's fair price for a nice grpahics demo with some awesome characters with well made faces and expressions and some fer hours of slaughter some barbarains. If you buy for a higher porice and expect a full fledged game, you will be disappointed. Since it still sells for 20 I have to be negative about it (bought it much cheaper).

If you are like me, then you have had a boyhood fascination with romans ever since you first saw Russel Crowe and his decidedly dodgy fringe, hacking up bad guys in the film Gladiator. If your like me you slavered over the stunning visuals that Ryse, son of Rome boasts, and couldn't wait to buy the game and dive head first into the historical, fantastical action.  I did just that and despite the gaming living up to the hype as far as graphics and voiceacting were concerned, it left me feeling somewhat deflated.   Firsty, let me just say that I really, really really wanted this game to be good. the Cinematic nature appealed to me when I first saw the trailer and I have to admit, the assassin's creed style, press and watch, style of combat was very cool. For the first hour or so. Unfortunately, stunning visuals, and they are stunning by the way, did very little to distract me from what felt like a very rushed, flat storyline.   The protagonist worked well as a character, but his story arc was as bland as the art designer's choice of enemy types. The words copy and paste can't help but spring to mind after hacking down your fiftieth enemy who bears more than a striking resemblance to the last guy that tried to kill you.   The game just is not long enough either. I completed the campaign in around three hours, and although the developers clearly idended a sort of gears of war esque co-op system for the multiplayer, it doesnt really provide any incentive to make you actually play with other people. You can literally do the whole thing yourself.   Finally. My biggest gripe with this game was how shockingly innacurate it was historically. I must have missed the part in my history books at school where Boudica led a grand invasion of Rome from the back of one of Hannibals war elephants, which he had kindly lent to her for the weekend.   All in all this game promises a lot but delivers very little. Its redeeming features are few and far between and even if bashing your head aganst hordes of identical siblings for fun is your thing; Dynasty warriors fans i'm looking at you, you would be hard pressed not to be annoyed at Ryse son of Rome.   To buy or not to buy? That may be the question you are considering and the choice is of course your own, but if i were looking for a cool, visually stunning game with romans in I'd buy Skyrim, play as an imperial and try my best to ignore the Dragons.   Happy Gaming.

This game is essentially a Flash game with great graphics and Roman inspired visuals. The game play is an exceedling over-managed experience, even for something that is a console port where such games are common, although not to this extreme. It's a corridor shooter with a knife.  The best thing about the game are the graphics and the setting. The Roman-inspired backdrops are quite good; but you can't interact with anything in the world--beyond the infrequent over managed color-coded 'click the Y button now' item. Don't worry about missing those or not figuring out what thing to click as there is only 1 way through every phase/level--remember, it's a corridor shooter in the worst sense.  The gameplay is dry, repetitive, and gets old fast; which is saying something for a 9 hour game. There's no camera customization options so you're stuck with the too close yo-bro-step-back default over-the shoulder camera. Might be a limitation of the engine, of the devs to add custom/zooming viewbox code, or simply console-SoP.  Regardless, probably around 7 hours in you might be finding it boring and/or irritating and want to accelerate to the end. Why? It's easy to delete, right? Well, gameplay is an excuse to show lots of cutscenes that make use of a really cool graphics engine we developed (seriously why else make games); and I think the character animation and corresponding voice-sync is indeed great. But ultimately it becomes irritatingly obvious that gameplay second, engaging interactive world second, engaging story second, everything second to showing off the cutscenes of our graphics engine.  The voice acting is quite excellent.  If you are at all a Rome aficonado, note carefully that this game takes place in alternative universe with no bearing on anything historical beyond some names that teens who skipped history class might still recognize from the multiple-guess tests they failed. In fact, those teens may have written the story for Ryse ([sic], should be Rise but friends of those same teens run the marketing department, fo' reelz).  If you can accept this minimal suspension of disbelief (ok, not minimal, but come on...game), you might want to pick up the game at a steep steep discount on top of a discount just to have a couple hours of fun swinging your spatha or coordinating some pila throwing with the other legionaries and maybe looking at all the lorica segmentata that is, well, everywhere. If Romans are your bag and you can do that, I'd definitely get it on that discount. It's all the sophistication of a Flash game or Candy Crush, but still...Romans.  Let's say $9-$12? Add an extra $1 if you will try multiplayer. Briefly.

I realize that for many people who believe that console gaming is the same thing as pc gaming, this will just seem natural. I do not think it is the right way to design a 'game', but so be it.  I did not have any issues with getting the game to run smoothly, I run an i7, win7, 660Ti, and it runs fine, but others have had issues with better hardware. I guess by now you have read many reviews that repeat the very same pros and cons again and again so I wont bother to repeat them here. What I will bother do however is say this: How the heck do people give to this game a very positive rating when the cons are so seriously and overwhelmingly bad? It is like rewarding the laziest possible attempt while at the same time we do recognize the lazyness involved. That is because you read a review, you see all the abysmally bad things mentioned in the cons... and then you see a thumbs up as well. WTH.  Yeah the graphics are neat... but also yeah... there are like 8 enemies cloned to death on a game where you actually do NOTHING else than seeing their faces, bodies and equipment while you quicktime event killing them again and again and again and again....  Yeah the moves are neat...but also yeah...there is absolutely no freedom, strategy, tactics or skill involved. In fact I would rather have the developers have a button, which if you were to press all the fights would be resolved automatically while you sit back and you enjoy a.... b-movie story with AAA movie production values. The fights after about half an hour or so get so boring that feel like a chore that you get to perform just to see the next awesome graphical setting.  Do not get the game if it is not on a 75% off sale, and even then you might think that your $5 could be much better spent on something else.  It is quite telling that I played this for about an hour and a half, I quit and I found myself playing Mount & Blade: Warband which has ABYSMALLY worse graphics, animation, production values...you name it... and nevertheless it is a vastly superior game. I am not trying to compare the two as they are completely uncomparable. Different genres, different styles, different everything. What I am trying to say is that graphics is not everything in a game, and in this particular case, although you cannot go much better than that graphics wise, the game feels so hollow that one has to wonder what the heck the developers were thinking.  And to go back to my initial point... what the heck the reviewers - that keep thumping it up - were thinking. Do they want companies to produce more games like this, or do they want to push gaming developers in a better direction?  I would give to this game a 2/10 while being extremely generous.
